document.docAuthor: Sottile, Salvatore & Nicholls, James A. & Cerasa, Giuliano
document.docTitle: Life cycle closure of Cerroneuroterus minutulus (Giraud, 1859) with C. aggregatus (Wachtl, 1880) (Hymenoptera: Cynipidae: Cynipini): experimental, taxonomic and molecular approaches

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Life cycle closure of Cerroneuroterus minutulus (Giraud, 1859) with C. aggregatus (Wachtl, 1880) (Hymenoptera: Cynipidae: Cynipini): experimental, taxonomic and molecular approaches

emphasis.docTitle:
Life cycle closure of
Cerroneuroterus minutulus ( Giraud, 1859 )
with
C. aggregatus ( Wachtl, 1880 )
( Hymenoptera : Cynipidae : Cynipini ): experimental, taxonomic and molecular approaches

subSection.paragraph: SALVATORE SOTTILE 1 , JAMES A. NICHOLLS 2 & GIULIANO CERASA 3,*

emphasis.docAuthorAffiliation: Museo Civico di Lentate Sul Seveso, Via D. Aureggi 25, 20823 Lentate Sul Seveso, Italy

subSection.paragraph: � salvatore.sottile73@gmail.com; https://orcid.org/0000-0002-3175-2550

emphasis.docAuthorAffiliation: Australian National Insect Collection, CSIRO, Clunies Ross Street, Acton, ACT 2601 Australia

subSection.paragraph: � james.nicholls@csiro.au; https://orcid.org/0000-0002-9325-563X

emphasis.docAuthorAffiliation: Department of Agricultural, Food and Forest Sciences (SAAF), University of Palermo, Viale delle Scienze Bd. 5A, 90128 Palermo, Italy

subSection.paragraph: � giucerasa@gmail.com; https://orcid.org/0000-0003-1837-4302

The life cycle of
Cerroneuroterus minutulus ( Giraud, 1859 )
, a species previously known only from its asexual generation, is closed. Our study demonstrates that
C. minutulus
exhibits the heterogony typical of Cynipini species, with alternating sexual and asexual generations. The identity of the sexual generation is demonstrated by laboratory experiments and confirmed by molecular data, with
Cerroneuroterus aggregatus ( Wachtl, 1880 )
determined to be the sexual generation, and junior synonym, of
Cerroneuroterus minutulus ( Giraud, 1859 )
. Illustrations and diagnoses for adults and galls, observations on biology and distribution information are provided as is a detailed redescription of the sexual generation of
C. minutulus
.

Key words: oak gallwasp , heterogonic life cycle , biology , sexual generation , taxonomy , morphology , distribution ,
Quercus

The family Cynipidae ( Hymenoptera : Cynipoidea) includes about 1,400 gall-inhabiting wasp species worldwide, distributed mainly throughout the Holarctic region ( Nieves-Aldrey 2001 ;
Stone et al. 2002
;
Csóka et al. 2005
; Melika 2006b ;
Avtzis et al. 2018
;
Hearn et al. 2024
), with the vast majority belonging to the tribe Cynipini and strictly associated with Fagaceae host plants, primarily of the genus
Quercus
. Within the Cynipini , the small genus
Cerroneuroterus Melika & Pujade-Villar, 2010
was established as a consequence of morphological and molecular phylogenetic studies that demonstrated the polyphyly of the genus
Neuroterus Hartig, 1840
. This genus, along with the re-established genera
Pseudoneuroterus Kinsey, 1923
,
Trichagalma Mayr, 1907
and
Latuspina Monzen, 1954
, includes those species previously placed in
Neuroterus
that are exclusively associated with
Quercus
section
Cerris
oaks (
Pujade-Villar et al. 2004
;
Melika et al . 2010
).

At the present time, the genus
Cerroneuroterus
includes six Western Palaearctic species:
C. aggregatus ( Wachtl, 1880 )
,
C. obtectus ( Wachtl, 1880 )
,
C. lanuginosus ( Giraud, 1859 )
,
C. minutulus ( Giraud, 1859 )
,
C. apenninus ( Trotter, 1923 )
and
C. gyulaigaraiae ( Melika, 2006a )
; plus four Eastern Palaearctic species:
C. folimargo ( Monzen, 1954 )
,
C. monzeni ( Dettmer, 1934 )
;
C. japonicus ( Ashmead, 1904 )
(=
C. vonkuenburgi ( Dettmer, 1934 ))
and
C. yukawamasudai Melika & Pujade-Villar, 2020
(
Melika et al. 2010
;
Pujade-Villar et al. 2020
;
Cerasa et al. 2021
;
Lobato-Vila et al. 2022
; see Table 1 for a summary of their biology). Of the 173 species of Cynipidae reported from Italy , four belong to the genus
Cerroneuroterus
:
C. lanuginosus
,
C. aggregatus
,
C. minutulus
and
C. apenninus
(
Massa et al. 2021
;
Cerasa et al. 2021
). Adults of the latter species were only recently described for the first time (
Cerasa et al. 2021
), and of these four species only
C. lanuginosus
has been demonstrated to show heterogony between alternating sexual and asexual generations. This alternating life cycle was recently established by
Shachar et al. (2018)
, who synonymised
C. cerrifloralis ( Müllner, 1901 )
under the name
C. lanuginosus ,
determining that the first is the sexual generation of the latter.

Cerroneuroterus minutulus
and
C. aggregatus
, both originally described in the genus
Neuroterus
, are also only known from a single generation each, asexual and sexual respectively. In the present study, we report the results of field observations and experiments, morphological identification and molecular assays which demonstrate that
C. minutulus
and
C. aggregatus
are alternate generations of the same species and we consequently propose that
C. aggregatus ( Wachtl, 1880 )
is a junior synonym of
C. minutulus ( Giraud, 1859 )
. We also provide information on the species’ distribution, illustrations and diagnoses for adults and galls of both sexual and asexual generations relative to similar Western Palaearctic similar congeners, plus a detailed redescription of the sexual generation of
C. minutulus
.

Cerroneuroterus species
, including which of their generation(s) are known, distributions, host plants and emergence times.

heading.emphasis: Additional material examined for morphological diagnosis

subSection.paragraph:
1 ♂ : ITALY : Emilia Romagna , Vernasca, (Piacenza), 44°45’38.6”N 9°48’46.8”E , 750 m , ex galls on
Quercus cerris
15.IV.2022 , emerged 27.IV.2022 , (sample N. 4497), S. Sottile leg. (GCPC). 1 ♂ : same label but emerged 30.IV.2022 , (sample N. 4498), S. Sottile leg. (MSNG). 1 ♀ : same label, but emerged 28.IV.2022 (sample N.4501), S. Sottile leg. (GCPC). 1 ♂ : ITALY : Emilia Romagna , Vernasca, (Piacenza), 44°45’38.6”N 9°48’46.8”E , 750 m , ex galls on
Quercus cerris
23.IV.2023 , emerged 10.V.2023 , (sample N. 4855), S. Sottile leg. (SSPC). 2 ♂ : same label but collected 15.IV.2023 , emerged 9.V.2023 , (sample N. 4856), S. Sottile leg. (SSPC). 2 ♂ : same label but collected 23.IV.2023 , emerged 30.IV.2023 , (sample N. 4857), S. Sottile leg. (MCLSS-SSPC). Sexual galls of
Cerroneuroterus aggregatus
preserved in the ‘Cecidotheca italica’ by Trotter & Cecconi at the Botanical Garden of Padua ( Fig. 15 ) with the following label:
Neuroterus aggregatus Wachtl
su [on]
Quercus cerris Appennino Ligure
: N. S. della Vittoria [Santuario of “Nostra Signora della Vittoria” in Mignanego municipality in the province of Genoa-Italy], 27.IX.1908 [collecting date], G. Mantero [Giacomo Mantero, leg.].

Laboratory and semi - field rearing assays were carried out following the experimental protocol described in
Sottile et al. (2022)
to which reference is also made for photos of experimental equipment. On 15 April 2022 , a dozen galls of sexual generation
C. aggregatus
were collected on
Quercus cerris
L. in the vicinity of Vernasca, Emilia Romagna , Italy ; with the help of a hacksaw, we made a cut to remove the three lumps of bark containing the galls. The galls, which had a purplish to greenish coloration, a succulent texture and a surface typically covered with fine granulation, were placed in a plastic jar with its bottom covered in cotton wool soaked with water, a necessary procedure to prevent dehydration and to keep the galls fresh until the growing larvae in them had completed their development.

On 24 April 2022 , a male was observed chewing an emergence hole and two more females emerged between 25 and 27 April. These insects were kept in an experimental “alcove” to improve sexual coupling for 4–8 hours and subsequently introduced into a “contact chamber” consisting of a tulle polyester bag (length: 70 cm ; width: 40 cm ; mesh size: 0.275 x 0.275 mm ; thread thickness: 50 µm) surrounding a branch of a pot grown tree of
Q. cerris
(12- years-old, labelled as “Cerro A”). To prevent oviposition by wild gall wasps, the branch chosen for the experiment had been enclosed in the contact chamber for about a month before the experiment started with the tulle bag positioned to ensure that the distance between tulle and the branch inside was at least 1 cm . The branch used in the experiment was chosen from a part of the tree that always remained in shady conditions to avoid a greenhouse effect inside the contact chamber, while at the same time with enough exposure to ensure good ventilation. Again consistent with the protocol developed by
Sottile et al. (2022)
, a vial containing water-saturated cotton wool was placed inside the contact chamber to provide water for the insects during egg-laying. The tree “Cerro A” was in a vigorous vegetative stage with growing leaves, and the insects inside the contact chamber laid eggs and remained active until 5 May 2022 ; two days later they were removed and mounted for subsequent morphological assessment.

Identification of adult wasps obtained from field collected galls and those used for the laboratory rearing experiments was performed using the keys and the morphological description provided by Melika (2006b) ,
Melika et al. (2010)
and Dalla Torre and Kieffer (1910) . The original descriptions by Giraud (1859) and Wachtl (1880) were also consulted. Insects were examined through Wild-Heerbrugg M8 (Wild Heerbrugg, Heerbrugg, Switzerland ) and Kyowa Optical SD-2PL stereomicroscopes (Kyowa Optical, Tokyo , Japan ) and with a Zeiss Universal Photomicroscope III compound microscope (Carl Zeiss, Oberkochen, Germany ). Images were taken using a Leica DM series compound microscope (Leica, Benzheim, Germany ) and a Leica DFC series mounted camera with Leica Application Suite software (LAS EZ 3.4.0, Leica, Switzerland ). All insect photos were integrated using the freeware CombineZP ( Hadley 2011 ) and processed in Adobe Photoshop CS4. Galls were photographed with Canon Eos 6D Mark II digital camera equipped with a Canon compact-macro lens EF 50 mm 1:2.5 and Canon macro lens EF 100 mm 1:2.8 L. (Canon Inc., Tokyo , Japan ).

Matching of these two
Cerroneuroterus
taxa as alternate generations of the same species was also confirmed using DNA data. Whole genomic DNA was extracted from one adult male
C. aggregatus
and two larvae dissected from developing galls of
C. minutulus
by incubating them overnight at 37°C in 40μL of a 10mM Tris solution to which 5μL of a 10mg /mL Proteinase K solution had been added. Sequence data were obtained for sections of two genes previously shown to be informative for matching alternate generations in cynipid gallwasps: the mitochondrial cytochrome b gene (cytb), and the second internal transcribed spacer region within the nuclear ribosomal cistron (ITS2) (see details in
Nicholls et al. 2012
, 2018, 2022). Amplified fragments of each gene were cleaned up with a standard SAP/Exo1 protocol and sequenced in both directions using BigDye v3.1 terminator chemistry run on an AB3730xl DNA Analyser at the ACRF Biomolecular Resource Facility, Australian National University. Base calling was checked and levels of variation between sequences determined using the software Sequencher version 4.10.1 ( Gene Codes Corporation 1995 ).

Laboratory Assays. The contact chamber was checked weekly and on 17 August 2022 galls of
C. minutulus
( Figs 1, 2 ) were observed on the upper surfaces of the leaves. The growing galls were a pale greenish or purplish color and showed the very pronounced coniform protrusions typical of this species, and they continued to develop until November 2022 .

On 22 February 2023 , when the leaves began to detach from the twigs, the galls ( 20 in total) were transferred to a plastic jar with tulle at the top and bottom which was then placed in a plastic box with the bottom covered with soil and rotting
Q. cerris
leaves to simulate the natural undergrowth litter. The box containing galls was then placed outdoors in a shady location, checked every two weeks, and water was added when needed to maintain substrate moisture. As no insects emerged during the spring of 2023, we hypothesise that the emergence of the agamic females may take place between December 2023 and January 2024 , two winters after the parental sexual generation and similar to that observed for the congeneric species
Cerroneuroterus apenninus .

Molecular results. ITS2 sequences were obtained for all three individuals examined (one sexual male
C. aggregatus
and two asexual
C. minutulus
) and cytb sequences from one individual of each generation. All three ITS2 sequences were identical, as were the two cytb sequences; this is the expected result for individuals of alternate generations of the same species that were obtained from experimental rearings of sequential generations. Sequences are deposited on GenBank, accession numbers OR805484–OR805485 and OR815387–OR815389.

The results of the field experiments, morphological identification and molecular assays demonstrate that
C. minutulus
represents the asexual generation of
C. aggregatus
. Therefore, according to the Principle of Priority in the International Code of Zoological Nomenclature ( ICZN 1999 ; art. 23.1 and 23.3.2.2) a new synonymy is here established:
Cerroneuroterus aggregatus ( Wachtl, 1880 )
as junior synonym of
Cerroneuroterus minutulus ( Giraud, 1859 )
.

bibRefCitation.author: Giraud, J. E.
bibRefCitation.refString: Giraud, J. E. (1859) Signalements de quelques especes nouvelles de Cynipides et de leurs Galles. Verhandlungen des Zoologisch-Botanischen Vereins in Wien, 9, 337 - 374.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Sexual galls ( Figs 9–15 ).
The sexual galls develop on adventitious buds mainly on large oak trunks ( Fig. 9–10 ), often in groups of 5–12, sometimes solitary; they are unilocular ( Fig. 11 ), sessile, sub-ellipsoidal in shape (ovoid) with major axis length 2.0– 2.3 mm , minor axis 1.8–2.1 mm . During the short growing phase, they have a succulent texture, with conspicuous red, purple and light green colouration ( Figs 10–12 ); their surface is granular, owing to the presence of a layer of large protruding cells ( Fig. 14 ), the walls often adorned with thin lamellae, vestiges of the transformed bud perulae ( Fig. 12 ); as they mature, the granulation is reduced by dehydration and the surface takes on a light brown colour and the walls become thin and coriaceous ( Figs 13–14 ). Sexual adults emerge from a large lateral hole and the galls are not deciduous and remain attached to the bark for a few years. Fresh galls obtained in this study were compared with those that were collected by Gaicomo Mantero in 1909 in Liguria ( Genoa province ) preserved in ‘Cecidotheca italica’at the Botanical Garden of Padua ( Fig. 15 ) (see “Additional material examined for morphological diagnosis”); both sets of gall were identical
.

subSection.paragraph:
The asexual generation gall of
C. minutulus
is similar in size and shape to the asexual gall of Drycosmus
destefanii Cerasa & Melika, 2018
from which it is clearly distinguishable by the presence of conical protrusions while in
D. destefanii
there are short filiform protuberances and the gall is red to brownish-red (
Cerasa et al. 2018
). Asexual galls of
C. minutulus
could be confused with galls of
Chilaspis nitida ( Giraud, 1859 )
and
Pseudoneuroterus saliens ( Kollar, 1857 )
when these are underdeveloped, young, aborted, parasitised or deformed by the presence of inquiline species. However, the surface of
Chilaspis
or
Pseudoneuroterus
galls does not show the characteristic coniform protrusions that are always the distinguishing feature of asexual
C. minutulus
galls.

This is a heterogonic species with a monoecic life cycle—hence shows obligate alternation between two generations, sexual and asexual, both forming galls on the same host plant or on a few closely related host plants always from
Quercus
section
Cerris
. Asexual generation galls have been recorded from the section
Cerris
oaks
Q. cerris
,
Q. libani , Q. ithaburensis
and the
Q. cerris
hybrid Q. x crenata . Sexual generation galls have only been found to date on
Q. cerris
but we suspect these more cryptic galls are also present on
Q. libani
and
Q. ithaburensis
in eastern parts of
C. minutulus
’ distribution.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 1–8. Asexual galls of
Cerroneuroterus minutulus
: 1–3, general appearance of growing galls; 4–7, mature galls; 8, dissected gall, showing the larval chamber.

FIGURES 9–15. Sexual galls of
Cerroneuroterus minutulus
: 9, the dotted circle indicates an area of a large turkey oak trunk rich in adventitious buds where the galls develop, the arrow shows the area from which the bark containing the galls used for experimental rearings was removed; 10–12, general appearance of and dissected growing galls; 13, 14, mature galls, with inset showing the histological preparation of gall surface; 15, galls preserved in the ‘Cecidotheca italica’ at the Botanical Garden of Padua, the inset shows their magnification (by courtesy of Padua University).

heading.emphasis:
Redescription of sexual generation of
Cerroneuroterus minutulus ( Giraud, 1859 )

subSection.paragraph:
The original descriptions of the sexual and asexual adults of
C. minutulus
are poor and lack detail; however, since we have not yet obtained asexual females, which are still in a diapaused larval stage in the galls we collected, for the moment we proceed here with a redescription only of the sexual generation.

Diagnosis. Sexual adults of
Cerroneuroterus minutulus
(=
C. aggregatus
) differ from the two other known sexual
Cerroneuroterus
in the Western Palaearctic (
C. lanuginosus
and
C. obtectus
) in the following characters, extracted from the keys in Melika (2006b) and Pujade-Villar (2007) . In sexual females
C. minutulus
the femurs are completely pale yellow, R1 vein is longer than 2r, the scutum and scutellum are both smooth and shiny. Sexual females
C. lanuginosus
differ in that their femurs are yellow only at the ends and are otherwise brown in their middle three quarters, R1 and 2r veins are equal in length, and sexual females
C. obtectus
differ by having the scutum and scutellum alutaceous or weakly coriaceous. In males
C. minutulus
F1 is clearly longer than F2, the central propodeal area has a median carina, the lateral ocellus nearly touches the compound eye with OOL = 0.6 times the diameter of the ocellus. In contrast, in males
C. lanuginosus
the distance between lateral ocellus and compound eye is equal to or greater than the diameter of the ocellus, and in
C. obtectus
F1 nearly equal to F2, the central propodeal area lacks a median carina.

Description: Sexual female. Head dark brown, mandibles, maxillary palps and labial palps light brown; antennae brown except for yellowish scape, pedicel, F1 and F2; eyes black. Mesosoma brown, legs yellow except for light brown coxae. Metasoma dark brown. Wings hyaline, veins yellow-brown to brown.
Body length 1.8–2.0 mm (N = 3).

Forewing ( Fig. 31 ) pubescent, 3.0 times as long as wide, hyaline, very weakly clouded around veins, 1.5 times as long as body, with distinct brown veins and moderately long marginal setae (marginal setae length/forewing width=0.07); radial cell open, 5 times as long as broad; R1 and Rs reaching wing margin and extending along it, R1 extending for half its length; first abscissa of radius (2r) curved, R1 longer than 2r; 2r–m curved; areolet distinct, triangular and large; 2r–m not extending along M vein; Rs + M distinct, reaching basal vein in the lower half. Hindwing ( Fig. 32 ), pubescent, hyaline, with very long marginal setae (marginal setae length/hindwing width=0.20), R 1 in the form of a narrow infuscate stripe on the anterior margin, starting from hamuli and extending along the margin for about 0.6 times its length.

FIGURES 27–38.

FIGURES 39–50.
Cerroneuroterus minutulus
male: 39, habitus; 40, head (front view); 41, antenna; 42, head (dorsal view); 43, head (ventro-frontal view); 44, proximal antennal segments; 45, mesosoma (lateral view); 46, forewing; 47, hindwing; 48, mesosoma (dorsal view); 49, metascutellum and propodeum (posterodorsal view); 50, metasoma (lateral view).

subSection.paragraph:
Although we have not yet reared the asexual generation of
Cerroneuroterus minutulus
, we provide a quick diagnosis of this generation relative to other Western Palaearctic asexual
Cerroneuroterus
following the keys in Melika (2006b) and
Cerasa et al . (2021)
plus details in Melika (2006a) . Asexual female
C. minutulus
differ from asexual
C. apenninus
,
C. lanuginosus
and
C. gyulaigaraiae
in that the genae are not broadened behind the eyes and the notauli are absent. In the other three species the genae are broadened behind the eyes and the notauli are complete (deeply impressed posteriorly and superficially in their anterior half in
C. apenninus
and
C. lanuginosus
, narrow and shallow in
C. gyulaigaraiae
).

The “life cycle closure” process, i.e. determining the previously unknown alternate generation of a heterogonic species or synonymizing two already described univoltine species (for example
Pujade-Villar et al. 2001
,
Rokas et al . 2003
,
Hood et al. 2018
), is complicated when dealing with Cynipini species as the adults and gall morphology of both generations can differ markedly. Rearing experiments are a crucial part of this process to assess complete life cycles (see for example
Pujade-Villar et al. 2003
,
Folliot et al. 2004
,
Folliot et al. 1964
,
Lund et al. 1998
,
Garbin et al. 2008
, Adler, 1881 ), but although an established way of matching generations they are often difficult and time-consuming. Some gall types do not rear well in controlled non-natural conditions, making it hard to obtain adults for morphological identification and subsequent oviposition experiments, and larval diapause (particularly of asexual generations) can significantly delay emergence of adults. However, in cases where obtaining adults of one generation is difficult then the species/generation-specific gall morphology can often act as a proxy for adult identification, as in this study of
C. minutulus
whereby the asexual gall morphology is clearly diagnostic despite adults not being reared.

Molecular methods can also allow for pairing of currently unmatched sexual and asexual generations into a single species’ life cycle, given that both generations within a species have got identical (or nearly so) DNA sequences (
Stone et al . 2008
,
Nicholls et al . 2018
,
Cerasa et al . 2020
). Single-gene methods can occasionally fail, for example in closely related species complexes where hybridisation sometimes occurs (see
Nicholls et al . 2012
), but a molecular approach whereby both mitochondrial and nuclear genes are used (as employed in this study) provides a more robust verification process. Molecular approaches to generation matching are also particularly useful in instances where adults of one generation are difficult to rear and only larvae of that generation are available for sequencing. This utility is demonstrated in this study and has also been previously demonstrated in a Nearctic Cynipini species,
Dryocosmus juliae
, whereby sexual adults and galls were matched to a recognised asexual gall morphology from which adults have not yet been successfully reared or formally described (
Nicholls et al . 2018
). However, ideally both experimental rearings and molecular data would be used for generation matching since the two approaches are complementary and mutually reinforcing as evidenced by this work.

The distribution and host plant associations of
C. minutulus
presented in Table 1 reflects our assessment of literature records and personal observations—it is a species restricted in range and hosts to southern, central and eastern Europe, Turkey and the Levant utilising the closely related host species
Q. cerris
(and some of its hybrids),
Q. libani
and
Q. ithaburensis
. There are, however, several records in the literature of
C. minutulus
from northern Africa galling
Q. suber
and its close relative
Q. afares
: in Tunisia ( Pujade-Villar & Ben Jamaa 2011 ; Pujade-Villar et al. 2011) and Algeria (
Pujade-Villar et al . 2012
;
Ghanem et al . 2016
;
Haddar et al . 2016
). However, the images of the asexual galls provided by Pujade-Villar & Ben Jamaa (2011 ; from Tunisia and replicated in
Pujade-Villar et al . (2012))
and
Haddar et al. (2016
; from Algeria ) are not typical of
C. minutulus
as they lack the conical protrusions covering the entire outer gall surface. Instead, they show the more pilose or filiform surface covering typical of galls induced by the asexual generation of the recently described species
Dryocosmus destefanii
which is known to gall the same host species,
Q. suber
, in nearby and phylogeographically-related Sicily. Hence, we consider that these African records originally assigned to
C. minutulus
actually correspond to
Dryocosmus destefanii Cerasa & Melika, 2018
.

We also would like to thank very much Rossella Marcucci from the Botanical Garden of Padua who kindly received and assisted during visit to the ‘Cecidotheca Italica’, the University of Padua which authorized the use of gall images in fig 15, Monica Bufo for her support in collecting and rearing galls and Maria Tavano and Roberto Poggi from Museo Civico di Stora Naturale “Giacomo Doria” Genoa (MSNG) for making available the collection of Cynipidae . The authors are also grateful to the two reviewers, Jose Luis Nieves-Aldrey and Juli Pujade-Villar, for their useful remarks and suggestions.
